Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The objective of this project is to create a student development system that provides domestic undergraduate electrical engineering students with a pathway to graduate school and employment in the high-tech sector of semiconductor devices. The scholarships funded with this grant, coupled with student development structures that emphasize mentorship and accountability, produce students who are poised to pursue graduate programs and subsequent full-time employment. This program capitalizes on an existing graduate level program with significant industrial support. Mentoring from a diverse group of faculty and alumni promotes participation by traditionally underrepresented groups. Scholarships and degree plans reduce the time to degree completion and improve scholastic performance by increasing focus on school work. Dissemination of program outcomes of this project is to facilitate wide-spread development of similar programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the Scholarships in Semiconductor Engineering (S-SDE) program was to create a student development system that provided a diverse group of domestic undergraduate electrical and computer engineering students with a pathway to graduate school and employment in the high-tech sector of semiconductor devices. The program enrolled eighty-four intellectually capable and motivated students were selected to receive scholarships for support during the junior and senior years of college. The scholarships were a critical part of the development pipeline that produced exceptional graduates, well prepared to pursue high-tech careers. A faculty mentoring program provided a high level of support and accountability for the students. Eight faculty members in the Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Department at Texas Tech University provided guidance to the program and mentoring to the students. 13-28 students per year were funded through NSF scholarships. 7-10 students per year were funded through scholarship support from Texas Instruments (TI). 100% of the students who completed the program found engineering employment or enrolled in graduate school.

Students selected for the program enrolled a 1 hour seminar that provided a number of career development opportunities including: (1) Tour of the X-FAB Texas semiconductor foundry in Lubbock, TX, (2) Texas Instruments (TI) informational meeting before each job fair (3) Q&A with a TI Vice President (4) internship guidance and recommendation, (5) resume, cover letter, and interviewing guidance (5) faculty mentoring.

The Intellectual Merit of the program included the comprehensive preparation of students for internship opportunities in high-tech industry through faculty mentoring, discussions with engineering hiring managers, plant tours, and resume/interview critiques. The Broader Impacts included producing a diverse group of graduates who will be valuable employees and strengthen their respective communities. Graduates are providing mentoring to current students and engineering outreach.
